thread.title: Appeals court rules against Trump's travel ban
thread.title_full: Appeals court rules against Trump's travel ban - seattlepi.com

author: DANIEL DEMAY, SEATTLEPI.COM STAFF
title: Appeals court rules against Trump's travel ban
text:
President Donald Trump's so-called Muslim ban remains on hold after a panel of federal appellate judges in San Francisco upheld a Seattle judge's ruling blocking the executive order.
The ruling sends the case back to federal court in Seattle, where Judge James Robart will soon hear the full case.
For now, those refugees and immigrants can enter the country.
"The government has taken the position we must not review its decision at all," the judges wrote in the ruling. "We disagree."
The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel in San Francisco heard arguments earlier in the week on the decision from U.S. District Judge James Robart, who blocked Trump’s executive order at the request of the state of Washington’s attorney general.
Related Stories The Trump order: 9th Circuit judges give verbal going-over to government lawyer Seattle judge halts nationwide enforcement of Trump's immigration order Washington is first state to sue Trump over immigration order The ruling effectively maintains the status quo until a full hearing is held on claims that Trump’s order violates the Constitution and federal law.
Any decision from the Ninth Circuit could see further appeal, though temporary, preliminary orders like Robart’s are not generally reviewed by higher courts.
The dispute centers on a lawsuit filed Jan. 30 by Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson. Attorneys for the state won a temporary pause on Trump’s executive order blocking entry to the U.S. by refugees worldwide and certain immigrants from seven Muslim majority nations.
Donald Trump is waiting with baited breath as the federal appeals court continues to mull over whether to keep Trump's executive ordered immigration ban that targets Muslim nations from entering or leaving the US. Not only will the results set Trump into a Twitter fury if they demolish the ban but President also has numerous lawsuits stacked on top of the case from people seeking relief for specific immigrants or by those standing up for several.
Media: MediaOS Video The appeals court ruling comes after an emergency hearing Tuesday that saw the three-judge panel grilling a Department of Justice attorney over the government’s defense of the order.
The decision is the latest action in what was the first suit by a state against Trump over the order. Since the lawsuit’s filing, Washington’s claims have been joined by Minnesota, and Amazon and Expedia have filed declarations in support of Ferguson’s position. A trove of statements to the court were filed as well, all in support of blocking the travel ban.
Judge Robart ruled in Seattle last Friday to approve a motion seeking the temporary restraining order that halted enforcement of Trump’s travel ban nationwide.
That ruling ended a week of confusion and frustration for those trying to get back to the U.S. who had been blocked by the ban. After the order was signed late Jan. 27, protests erupted nationwide as federal employees began turning away nationals traveling from the seven predominantly Muslim nations specified in the order.
